content:
Please update Test Case 7 title to:

Take one and add

I just pressed the Approve button but Remi beat me to it!
I think the puzzle is very well done - clear instructions and thorough test cases.
I found it a bit harder than most Medium puzzles, but easier than most Hard puzzles, so I think the rating is fine.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The contribution is among the most interesting, the original game is well respected, and the tests contain all the possible pitfalls to help with debugging. Very nice work.
I can't approve (yet?) because I didn't solve it, but for sure it looks really interesting. I played this game a lot with my parents when I was a child.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Re-Approving

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving. Reasons below.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The tests cases are thorough and the statement covers every aspect. As claimed, it doesn't require much optimization (compared to part 2) to pass the last tests.

It is probably on the higher end of the medium puzzles, but also noticeably easier than the second part (from the very few testcases that I tried and failed). All in all, I think the difficulty is appropiate.

Fantastic puzzle, and very nice (2, 3 month?) work both from @jddingemanse and @cedricdd.
What's the reason behind the COMBINE insert index being "highest rowid that existed + 1" instead of the lowest index available?

I'm trying to solve this one and stumbled upon this behaviour. I haven't tried to fix it and I don't know if it's worth mending. I'll let you decide.

Basically my current solution passes tests 13 & 15 & 17 but not their respective validators (so no feedback is given to me as to why my code is wrong).

I will send you the code by PM. It is not commented, nor very readable.

Nice puzzle so far.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really like this puzzle and the second part, had fun solving it.
The statement is explaining the rules clearly & everything is tested with the many validators.

Interesting looking Puzzle!

As @5DN1L has already suggested corrections and advice, I have nothing to add.

I cannot approve as I am below "LVL 20+" of approval and rejection decisions... but I would approve if I could.

[UPVOTED]
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Goal
* Paragraph 1:
  â€¢ Suggest to add "all" before "relevant aspects".
  â€¢ Suggest to change "exceeded" to "exceeds".

* Suggest to change "contribution" to "puzzle" (6 times).

* Last part:Â Link to Part 2 to be updated to link to puzzle instead of link to contribution.

Output
* Please mention "one action per line" and "one row per line".

Constraints
* Please delete the constraint on jokers, as it's irrelevant to Part 1.

Cover picture
* ðŸ˜‰

Cases
* Suggest to rearrange the rows of the test or the validator so that they are slightly more different:
  â€¢ Pair 9
  â€¢ Pairs 11 to 14
  â€¢Â Pairs 17 to 21 

Thanks.

Hi,

"gets a new rowid (highest current rowid + 1)" this is misleading, for example in test 19 when the insert is done the highest current rowid is 1 as there is only row left but the new row takes the ID 4, it's not the "highest current rowid + 1" but the "highest rowid that existed + 1";

In constraints you can remove "There is never more than 1 Joker."

I'm currently building a new code from 0, that's just trying every actions, that would make this puzzle fit in the medium category, will report on tests missing once I'm done.

After bumping into the case-limit of 25 cases, I have decided to split the Rummikub contribution into two parts. To make a relevant split, in this part 1 only the 'easier' cases are included:
- No Joker tile;
- Not too many rows, and a maximum of 7 actions needed for each case, meaning that you can pretty much solve this by simply trying all actions in any possible order without timing out.
I therefore hope the CG community agrees this is a Medium-level puzzle, and that the Rummikub 2 as Hard-level puzzle is a valid separate contribution.

I keep this (and Rummikub 2) in WIP at the moment, because with this split into two contributions I can suddenly look for extra cases to include again :-). Feel free to suggest some!

Here's my take on tests/Validators:

- Add to run (start) => 1 & 2
Adding a test & validator where you just directly add at the end of a run
- Add to run (end)  =>
Example:
7R
2
1 4R 5R 6R
2 4B 4G 4Y
- Add to set => 3 & 4
- Insert to run (middle) => 5
- Insert to run (not middle) => 6
I would add a test where you insert a tile that's not the middle tile & a validator where you insert the middle tile just for consistency.
- Choose the run => 7 & 8
- Take one and add (end) => 9
- Take one and add (start) => 10
Again  for consistency I would have a test & a validator where you add the tile taken to the start & the end.
- Take one and insert => 11 & 12
- Split => 13 & 14
- Switch => 15 & 16
- Combine for first => 17
- Combine for last => 18
Again  for consistency I would have a test & a validator where the combine is done to take the first and then the last tile of the combine row.
- Combine priority
Add a test & validator specifically to check for combine priority
Example:
8B
5
1 6B 7B 8B 9B
2 5B 6B 7B 8B 9B
3 4B 4G 4R 4Y
4 10B 11B 12B
5 5B 5G 5R 5Y
- Combine to insert => 19 & 20
- Combine to take => 21 & 22
- Prepare for the split (before) => 23 & 24
Adding a test & validator where you split on the tile after in order to insert, like it's done for 23 & 24 on the tile before.
- Prepare for the split (after) =>
Example:
8Y
3
1 7Y 8Y 9Y 10Y
2 9B 9G 9R 9Y
3 11B 11G 11R 11Y
- You take some, you put some => 25 & 26
- Limit test
Example:
4B
12
1 4B 5B 6B
2 12B 12G 12R 12Y
3 3B 3G 3Y
4 2R 3R 4R 5R
5 6G 7G 8G
6 4B 4G 4R 4Y
7 7B 8B 9B
8 3R 4R 5R 6R
9 9Y 10Y 11Y
10 2B 2G 2R 2Y
11 9G 10G 11G
12 10B 10G 10R 10Y
This one for example takes me ~0.2s with the brute force testing all the moves.

The "consistency " stuff is to make sure you don't run into the case where you can pass all the tests but you have a validator that fails because they don't check the same thing (one a action done at the start, the other the same action done at the end).

My code for V1 hits "Fatal error: Allowed memory size" on test "A lot is irrelevant" for V2
Done (except for the link), thanks a lot as usual!

Thanks! I did not realize there is a LVL difference between being allowed to approve clashes and puzzles.

And, while I have your attention, I have a question concerning difficulty level. I started with one Rummikub contribution (on Hard), but I had to split it into 1 and 2 due to number of cases. I put Rummikub 1 on Medium, since it is meant to be easier than Rummikub 2. Do you have an opinion on the difficulty level: do you agree with Medium for this one?
Thanks a lot for your time and extremely helpful feedback during the creation of this contribution (and Rummikub 2)!

Awesome that you started checking! I reacted by PM; for some reason your current code can deal with the row-order of tests 13/15/17 but not of validators 14/16/18.

The intent of all cases (for Rummikub 1 and Rummikub 2) is that tests and validators are very much similar - except that the rows are in a bit of a different order, and tile number / colors are (consistently) changed. The number of steps and kind of steps required for test and validator is in all cases identical.
In other words: you actually surprise me (again) with writing code that passes tests but not corresponding validators. At this moment my assumption is that also for any future such issue, it can only because of row order.

And, I expect that this order problem you now encounter will have to be solved anyway for later tests/validators as well, so I expect it is not something that will creep up only in validators. If for some reason in later tests/validators you see similar behavior (passing tests but not validators), then I will mix a couple of the tests and validators around to get the order problem also in the tests. But that is statistically unlikely, given that I randomly shifted the row orders around.

I'm not sure I fully understand your question. The COMBINE action leads to the merging of two runs into one run. "The new run gets the lowest rowid ([[rowid1]]), the other rowid ([[rowid2]]) becomes unused."
Eg:
1 3G 4G 5G
2 6G 7G 8G
COMBINE 1 2
1 3G 4G 4G 6G 7G 8G
[2 becomes unused]

COMBINE makes a row disappear. The "highest rowid that existed + 1" is for the case of the creation of an extra row: a 'split' action. In that case, I did not want the extra row to get a rowid that was earlier used for something else, for table visuality (row x in output will either be the original row x, a changed row x due to added/taken tiles or COMBINE, or it will be unused - it will never be a completely other row). I just want a kind of autistic 'COMBINE makes a row disappear, split makes a new row appear', without those two interacting.
Awesome, thanks for taking the time and thanks for the positive feedback!

Yeah same for me, really a childhood game. I picked it up again a couple of months ago, and then thought 'lets build a solver'. I absolutely did not anticipate that a game that children play could be so hard to code (for me at least); I utterly failed with a full solver, so the contributions I submitted are a simplified version of the real Rummikub.
Thanks a lot for the nice feedback and taking your time!
Hah wow four approvalsðŸ˜„, thanks for your nice feedback. If you still want your name seen as approver connected to Rummikub: there is still place left at Rummikub 2ðŸ˜.
Done, thanks. Back in the game? ðŸ˜€

Maybe a missing rule ...
If I have 2 lines :
1 6R 7R 8R
2 3R 4R 5R
and I want to combine, do I have to print "COMBINE 2 1" or "COMBINE 1 2" or whatever ?
(when the line 2 is before the line 1 in the result of the combination)

You must print COMBINE 1 2. The following section of the statement is supposed to cover that, especially the second sentence:
"
â€¢ A COMBINE action can be used to merge two runs into one longer valid run. Order the rowids from the two rows numerically. The new run gets the lowest rowid (rowid1), the other rowid (rowid2) becomes unused."
Let me know if that does not sufficiently cover it in your opinion.
Yes it is, my bad, I didn't see it.

My solution is nearly finished. I can list of the possible actions on a given game state, and I  simulated each possible action. Now I just need to do a BFS then to approve your contribution.

I didn't see any bug, you've already debuged everything with Cedric and Rafa ^^

The puzzle would be much better with a referee and graphics, but you've already done a good job.

Cool! You're right, there has been quite some back and forth with Cedric and Rafa. Quite a bit of that happened on the part 2 contribution (which was the original one, before I split it into two parts).

I've no experience yet with referee and graphics - is that something that can be done in combination with classic in/out puzzles, or is it only for specific contribution types? And if it's possible with in/out, can I also implement that after the contribution is approved and went live?

Apologies, probably things that I can also find somewhere in documentation.

No you can't, you have to choose "solo game" when creating a contribution, and it's not easy to do. There is a documentation but it's still not easy.

I don't suggest to modify your contribution now.

Ah ok. Maybe something for Rummikub 2, if that one keeps hanging unapproved a long time after Rummikub 1 gets approval. Or a Rummikub 3 if at some later stage I manage to create a full(er) solver (with two jokers and as many takes or puts as you want in any order and multiple goaltiles, just like the real rummikub)

:crying:  your f*cking validators are pissing me off ^^

I'm on the last test, with a tile identical to the tile to put.

Whoops I hope your frustration does not result in a rejectionðŸ˜….

With 'validators', do you mean all tests and how they cover different edges, or do you specifically mean the validators (as in, you are having difficulty with some validators while their corresponding tests are fine - implying imbalance between tests and validators)?
Last test and last validator.

Ah ok and nevermind, just see your approval, thanks!

To doublecheck your approval: do you agree with Medium level scaling?
Yes, there is no big difficulty. I didn't have to optimize my computations.

Sorry that was an oddly phrased.

I meant that up to "Combine to insert" it worked fine with no mutation of an extra variable. I could just do rows[len(rows)] = newrow when splitting.

The off bit of logic was indeed at the PUT action level, but it didn't show up until some rows were deleted with COMBINE.

It was a bit tricky because I generate all the actions at some point then yield them if the are valid, but mutating that "highest rowid that existed" required checking that both the action was valid and that a split was performed in that PUT action.

Yeah the rows[len(rows)] would anyway cause a problem after COMBINE, because that would not imply the lowest available id, but simply the highest id based on current rows. Due to combine of rows 1,2,3 row 2 can disappear, so for rows[len(rows)] to work then during disappearance of row 2, row 3 should also silently become row 2. That is behavior I don't want; I want the output to be linked directly to the input (i.e. I want for a row 3 I see in output to be sure that I can see the origins of that row also in row 3 of the input, rather than that a row 3 in output could have come from anywhere).

But I understand the trickiness - for coding it would be easier to have at all times simply nrows == max(rowids). Apologies :-).
Makes complete sense. Thank you.

NB "the off bit of logic was at the PUT action level": split can both happen due to PUT and TAKE, so you might run into the same issue with a TAKE split (or, possibly, there is not a case with a TAKE split and COMBINE together).
PUT and TAKE are the the same for me atm. I will keep it mind nonetheless. Thank you.
Fyi: I shifted test and validator for 13/14 and 17/18, to break the pattern you encountered.

Ok, thanks.

I finally reached the last test and it seems I will have to work hard to pass that one. I ran it locally for 5 mins and it didn't find a solution lol.

Oh hmm I meant to have it as kind of a longer but not too long test. Let me wait for a bit whether you can find some obvious time reducer, but I 'promised' that this contribution should be possible without code optimization, so if it takes you too much work I should reduce that test.

There's really a lot of possible optimizations to me code. Since I don't know what sweet spot you had in mind the only thing I can do is to send you my code by PM and let you decide.

Now what I will try to do first is to not copy the whole object (!) every time I try a PUT/TAKE action at line 173, much in the likes of what I did in like 200+ with the COMBINE.

For your information: I changed (shortened) the final case/validator. I wrote solution code again from scratch, without any optimization in mind (just checking every option for every tile along every step), and then I got a timeout problem at this final one. Since I do not want players to be bothered by code optimization this contribution, I have reduced the number of non-relevant rows in that case/validator. Now my non-optimized code solves it in 1500 ms.
Yeah. Medium suits it. I think its fine.

Oh one question: given that this contribution can be solved brute-force (simply check all combinations of actions, and you will reach a solution before time-out), is it a good idea to add 'brute force' as tag? (And, any other suggestions regarding the tags I chose and other tags that there are out there?)

Sure, go ahead! The tag in use is "Brute-force" with a hyphen in it and with the first letter capitalised.

I don't have any other suggestions on the tags.

This is gold, thanks! I'll process it over the coming days.

To be sure I understand you correctly: with the consistency stuff you mean that if a test requires to add at the end, the validator should do exactly the same, right? (meaning to say that for example at this moment insert to run test and validator are not consistent; I should make them consistent?)

NB: my code for V1 simply times out for V2. But anyway, good sign that there is a clear difference between V1 and V2 and that you can simply brute-force V1.

Your proposed limit test is not valid, because there are (including goalTile) in total 3x 4B. But it did tell me I need to double-check my solution code - my code makes a mistake with that case (and that is not because of the 3x 4B). Possibly I cleaned a bit too much when going from V2->V1 with my solution code.

Oh I honestly didn't pay attention to  the 3 limit when building it, just randomly filling empty rows, be changing row 6 to "6 13B 13G 13R 13Y" I think it makes it valid (that row isn't used to solve it).

For 'consistency' yeah that's what I meant, technically they check the same principle but it can be done by the different ways, since you still have a bunch of test available I think it's better to check everything in tests and in validators.

How long does your code take with the limit test I added at the end? ( I'm still going to add a bunch of extra tests/vals based on your suggestions, but your limit test with the 3rd 4B removed and adding two other rows instead I already liked to include) My V1 code takes 2s, I think I should not go much more than that in this Rummikub 1 contribution.

NB compliments for building a test that qualifies as a limit test but still neatly sticks to the constraint of 7 steps I included.

For "Test Limit" I'm at ~0.7s and "Validator 14" at ~1.5s with PHP so a slow language.

In Validator 14, the sets at line 2 & 10 are not valid, the colors are not in the right order.

Hah that's interesting that the validator takes 2x as long as the test - I just shifted BGRY around (which explains the invalid set orders, I'll fix that). But anyway if both Python and PHP take 1-2 seconds I think we are safe with the limit test.

Ok, I added all of them, with one remark: I need to come up with a better 'Combine priority' case (current 29/30). I understand the case you propose, but by having two possible rows to combine, there is 3x the same tile (8B). I'm not at my sharpest now, tomorrow I'll try to come up with a valid case that checks for combine priority.

I've updated the Combine priority case. Actually, I came up with the rule on combine priority for the situation where you have to combine two times (for example, rows 1G 2G 3G, 4G 5G 6G, 7G 8G 9G, where you can combine 1 2 and then 1 3, but also 2 3 and then 1 2). The case you built (and that I have tried to honor) is instead about multiple options for a similar action. That brings us into a direction I am not sure I fully like (I fully left out the duplicate rows or the option to take a tile from multiple rows and that you have to pick one of them, because, if I would include that it would warrant a whole load of new cases, and the dynamic it tests is not really about Rummikub anymore, but on consistent row selection).

I am fine with including this Combine priority case (I altered the combine priority rule a bit by adding 'COMBINE 2 6 before COMBINE 3 4'), but it opens a new area (testing to choose between rows 1 2 versus 3 4, but also 1 4 versus 2 5 and 1 6 versus 2 3) that I do not want to enter any further than this.
It's fine if you drop that test, I get the reasoning. It doesn't look like what I wanted to test is possible without having duplicate rows or having 3 identical tiles so it doesn't need to be tested.
